Expectation1: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation1: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: Sunday morning sunlight streamed through my window as I buttoned my shirt, ready for church. My phone buzzed—an unknown number. I hesitated, then answered. “This is Jamie from Senator Lee’s office. The Senator’s available for ten minutes to discuss the bill you’ve been advocating. Can you talk now?” My heart pounded. This was the moment I’d been working toward for months, a chance to make real change. But the church service started in fifteen minutes, and I was supposed to help lead the opening prayer. Pastor Miller had reminded me last night how important it was to be present, especially as a role model for the youth group. I stared at my reflection, torn. My church family expected my commitment, my presence, my faith in action. But the activist in me knew this call could be the breakthrough we needed. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my loyalty, each asking me to choose.
